Award.AwardTitle: Implementation Project: Utica Campus Community College Transformation HBCU-UP Initiative

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Utica Campus of the Hinds Community College District's project entitled: The Utica Campus Community College Transformation HBCU-UP Initiative, seeks to develop educational bridges that provide greater opportunities in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) workforce for their students. The overarching goal of the UC3T initiative is to more than double the number of students who complete work at HCC prepared to pursue B.S. degrees at four-year institutions by strengthening bridges that support students' matriculation from high school to community college and from community college to degree-granting institutions in pursuit of a B.S. degree in STEM. Jackson State University is forming an alliance to support students from the HCC district matriculating to JSU to pursue degrees STEM fields.

The UC3T Initiative addresses a number of aspects of student and faculty development in STEM. Seven components comprise the UC3T initiative: (1) pedagogical transformations involving process education strategies, (2) faculty preparedness bridges, (3) cyber-institutional renewal, (4) seamless articulation, (5) joint academic bridges, (6) research experiences for undergraduates, and (7) the creation of a STEM community college science diversity center ? all designed to increase the enrollment, retention, and graduation and transfer rate of Utica Campus STEM students. These components were selected based on a comprehensive needs assessment including faculty and student surveys.

This project can serve as a national model to encourage student matriculation from community colleges to degree granting institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hinds Community College – Utica Campus (HCCUC) received an NSF Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) grant titled, The Utica Campus Community College Transformation (UC3T) HBCU-UP Initiative. The award was funded in October 2010 and lasted through September 2016. The overarching goal was to more than double the number of STEM students who complete associate degrees at HCCUC who were prepared to pursue bachelor’s degrees. The project’s success was evident in increases in enrollment, completion and matriculation. Enrollment in STEM increased by 225 percent (from 20 students to 65 students) over the grant. The goal was accomplished by strengthening students’ community college academic experiences and by developing bridges and transitional points that supported students’ matriculation from one education level to the next in pursuit of a bachelor’s degree in STEM. HCCUC and Jackson State University (JSU) formed a new articulation alliance to link students from the HCC district to JSU’s STEM programs.

During the project, building institutional capacity to strengthen all STEM offerings was paramount to the success of STEM students. Evidence-based instructional practices adopted by the HCCUC included incorporating active learning approaches, extensive training, and modeling of Process Education principles. 100% of the faculty at HCCUC was trained in Process Education Principles. Process Education (PE) is a performance-based philosophy of education, which integrates many different educational theories, processes, and tools in emphasizing the continuous development of learning skills using assessment principles that produce learner self-development. Process Education principles were incorporated into all of STEM courses – sciences, technology, and mathematics.

Each summer, a pre-college summer bridge program was held to support student preparedness for under-prepared minority high school seniors transitioning to the college. The Learning to Learn Camp focused on 1) challenging and inspiring students to grow and develop skills essential for success in college and beyond; and 2) motivating faculty and staff to mentor student growth and improve the teaching/learning processes they use with students. The camp integrated two key processes, learning how to learn and mentoring. The learning community environment of the camp taught students to build relationships, gain a sense of “belonging” and improve their ability to perform successfully in the classroom, which are all factors critical to student retention.

The program served students, who were largely academically underprepared, but, with appropriate interventions and supports, were assessed as having the potential for success in STEM education and careers. A total of 105 STEM majors were supported with financial assistance, faculty mentors and professional development opportunities; however, 62% were retained until graduation. All those who were retained in the program were able to graduate in 2 years.

Before the grant, research was not a major focus within the community college system. Consequently, there was limited research activity conducted by faculty, which means there was limited opportunities for students’ exposure and participation in research. UC3T HBCU-UP exposed students to research, both as an enriching educational experience and in preparation for their transition to four-year institutions. The Summer Nanotechnology Accelerator Partnership research activities were held in the summers of 2012, 2013 and 2015. Over the three summers, 37 HCCUC campus students, and 4 faculty members participated in hands-on activities, workshops and site visits to research facilities. This structured, multi-institutional research project was the first of its kind at HCCUC.

The program’s impact on students in the program led to early research experiences and exposure at a national conference. At the 2016 Emerging Researchers National (ERN) Conference in Washington, D.C., three (3) STEM-UP participants presented research at poster sessions they conducted in the summer of 2015 during the STEM-UP Nanotechnology Summer Research. Additional dissemination included HCCUC administrators and STEM faculty presenting at the League for Innovation in the Community College STEMtech Conference in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

With the development of new technologies, the “Creation of a Community College Science Diversity Center (C2SDC)” which is now the CyberMentoring Network (CMN) became mobile. I-Pads were rewarded to students who completed their associate’s degree and transferred to a 4-year institution and loaned to faculty to use to create the CMN. Faculty members were trained to mentor students who graduated and transferred to 4-year institutions using WebEx as a communication tool, and also how to teach with technology. The CMN, as was the case for the C2SDC, was designed to support students transfer from community college to universities.
